name: Retention
description: Retention across these episodes is treated as the clearest proof of real product value and the foundation of durable growth—more reliable than acquisition spikes or funnel optics. The theme covers how to define and measure “coming back,” design product systems that build habits and repeat value, and run experimentation and monetization in ways that improve long-term customer outcomes rather than short-term metrics.
subtopics: How to define true retention: core action, frequency targets, and cohort-based measures vs. vanity metrics
Activation-to-retention connection: getting users to the first moment of value and repeatedly back to it
Habit and engagement loops: streaks, notifications, rewards, and “flexibility” mechanics that prevent drop-off
Experimentation for retention: high-volume testing, guardrails, long-term measurement, and avoiding local maxima
Segmentation and ideal customer focus: identifying “must-have” users, mapping the end-to-end journey, and designing for expansion
Retention vs. churn tradeoffs: when churn is acceptable (or strategic) and how business model/pricing changes retention incentives
common_frameworks: Cohort retention analysis (e.g., D1/D7/D30, weekly retention, retention curves)
North Star Metric design tied to repeat value (e.g., frequency-based metrics like D5/D7)
Core action / value moment identification (activation that predicts long-term retention)
Sean Ellis PMF test (“very disappointed”) as a leading indicator, with retention as confirmation
Customer-led journey mapping (including pre-awareness and post-acquisition retention/expansion)
High-tempo experimentation systems (test pipelines, guardrails, and long-term holdouts/measurement)
